questions.question: An intern reviewing an MRI scan observes a "boxcar ventricle” This radiological finding is indicative of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: boxcar-shaped ventricles due to the enlargement of the lateral ventricles. Huntington's Disease Definition Hereditary neurodegenerative disorder characterized by chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and cognitive decline. Inheritance Pattern Autosomal dominant due to a mutation in the HTT gene on chromosome 4 involving a CAG trinucleotide repeat. Clinical Features Chorea: Involuntary, irregular movements. Mood Changes: Irritability and aggressive behavior. Cognitive Decline: Progressive memory loss (dementia). Radiological Findings Atrophy of Caudate Nucleus: Leads to dilation of the frontal horn of the lateral ventricle. "Boxcar Ventricles" Appearance: Resulting from caudate atrophy. Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) (Option A) Definition A rapidly progressive neurodegenerative disorder caused by prions—misfolded proteins that induce other proteins to misfold, leading to brain damage. Clinical Features Cognitive Decline: Rapid deterioration of mental function. Behavioral Changes: Altered behavior and personality. Myoclonus: Sudden muscle jerks. Radiological Findings Diffusion-weighted MRI Findings: Increased signal intensity in the basal ganglia (particularly in the putamen and caudate nuclei) and cortical ribboning. Ventricular Enlargement: Atrophy leading to enlarged ventricles Variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (vCJD) A subtype of CJD associated with consumption of beef products contaminated with BSE (bovine spongiform encephalopathy). Radiological Findings Cortical Atrophy: Particularly in the occipital and parietal lobes. Increased Signal Intensity on MRI: Observed in affected areas, especially in the basal ganglia and cerebral cortex. Pulvinar Sign (Image A): Increased signal intensity in the pulvinar nucleus of the thalamus. Hockey Stick Sign (Image B): A characteristic appearance on MRI, indicating involvement of the posterior thalamus. Pick’s Disease (Frontotemporal Dementia) (Option C) Definition A type of frontotemporal dementia characterized by early changes in personality, behavior, and social conduct. Affected Areas Primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Clinical Features Behavioral Abnormalities: Significant personality changes and social withdrawal. Radiological Findings Prominent Sulci in the Frontal Lobe: Indicates atrophy of the frontal lobe. Symmetric Disproportionate Atrophy of the Frontal Lobe: A hallmark distinguishing it from other forms of dementia. Alzheimer’s Disease (Option D) Definition The most common form of dementia, marked by progressive memory loss, cognitive decline, and changes in behavior and personality. Pathophysiology Accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the brain. Clinical Features Memory Impairment: Often the earliest symptom reported is difficulty remembering recent events. Radiological Findings Bilateral Symmetric

questions.question: A 3-year-old child presents with progressive motor decline, cognitive regression, and spasticity. MRI shows confluent and symmetric hyperintense T2 signals in the periventricular and deep white matter, with sparing of subcortical U fibers & tigroid pattern is noted. What is the underlying enzymatic deficiency? C. β -Galactocerebrosidase deficiency
questions.explanation: periventricular white matter changes and the characteristic tigroid pattern on MRI. Metachromatic leukodystrophy Caused by a deficiency of the enzyme Arylsulfatase A (Option B) Characterized by confluent and symmetric hyperintense T2 signals in the periventricular and deep white matter , while subcortical U fibers are relatively spared. The perivenular myelin shows relative sparing , creating a tigroid pattern. Alexander disease Three clinical forms exist: infantile, juvenile, and adult, with the infantile form being the most common, presenting with macrocephaly . Characteristic T2 hyperintense signal in bifrontal white matter . Early disease may show intense post-contrast enhancement. Histopathologically characterized by Rosenthal fibers in the brain. Adrenoleukodystrophy An inherited X-linked peroxisomal disorder caused by a mutation in the ABCD1 gene .

questions.question: A 75-year-old female presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive difficulty in walking, frequent urinary urgency, and occasional episodes of confusion. Imaging is performed, revealing ventriculomegaly and effacement of the sulci at the vertex as shown. Which of the following statements about the condition is false?

options.A: It is idiopathic but can be caused due to past injuries
options.B: The Evans ratio is less than 0.31
options.C: The callosal angle is less than 90 degrees
options.D: A disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space is seen

questions.explanation: is more than 0.31 . Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) NPH is often idiopathic but can result from prior injuries affecting cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage. (Option A) Clinical presentation Gait disturbance: progressive difficulties in walking Urinary issues: urgency or incontinence Cognitive impairment: decline in cognitive functions Imaging Characteristics Ventriculomegaly is typically seen Evans ratio : the ratio of the maximum width of frontal horns to inner table width of more than 0.31 is often used for evaluation but has low diagnostic accuracy. An acute callosal angle (less than 90°) on coronal MR images is another measurement used, also with limited accuracy. (Option C) A disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space hydrocephalus (Option D) is seen having ventriculomegaly combined with sulcal effacement at the vertex and scattered enlarged sulci. CSF flow study shows hyper-dynamism with a streak of flow void through cerebral aqueduct.

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatric neurologist with a history of recurrent seizures since he was 1 year old. Upon examination, a port wine stain is noted on the right side of his face. What imaging findings would you expect to see in this patient, considering Sturge–Weber Syndrome?

options.B: Cystic lesions with enhancing mural nodules in the cerebellum
options.C: Tramline calcifications and atrophy of the affected hemisphere

questions.explanation: of the affected hemisphere, are seen as later findings, that is, after 2 years of the child, which is the case depicted here with a 6-year-old child. Sturge–Weber Syndrome (SWS) It is a congenital syndrome characterized by a facial port-wine stain (nevus) and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas, typically located in the parieto-occipital region. Clinically present with: Focal seizures often begin in the first year of life and may become refractory later Developmental delay Progressive hemiparesis Hemianopsia Intellectual impairment Glaucoma (Unilateral) Imaging findings: Early Imaging: CT and MRI may appear normal initially as pial angiomas may not be noticeable before age 2 . (vs Option A) By age 2 , " tramline calcifications " may be visible on skull radiographs due to chronic ischemia. The affected hemisphere shows atrophy and progressive cortical calcification. A pial angioma is seen as diffuse pial enhancement, with possible variable thickness on imaging. Other Findings: enlargement of the ipsilateral choroid plexus and dilation of veins connecting superficial and deep venous systems. Late imaging: Burnt Out Cases: in chronic cases, the pial angioma may no longer be detectable, leaving a shrunken, calcified hemisphere. Polymicrogyria may be observed in some children with SWS. Ataxia-telangiectasia Ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T) is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder linked to a mutation in the ATM gene located on chromosome 11 (11q22–23). Clinical features: Eye and skin telangiectasia Immunodeficiency Neurological issues Imaging findings: MRI is the primary neuroimaging technique for A-T due to its superior tissue contrast and lack of ionizing radiation The most consistent finding is cerebellar atrophy (Option D) Cerebral white matter abnormalities are observed in some adult patients T1 and T2-weighted images show multiple hypointense foci suggestive of hemosiderin from leaks or hemorrhages T2/FLAIR hyperintensities resembling leukodystrophy Von Hippel–Lindau Syndrome Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder caused by the inactivation of a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3p25.5. This syndrome is characterized by the development of hemangioblastomas, which are primary CNS tumors that can affect both the spinal cord and brain, particularly in the cerebellum and brainstem. Imaging appearance: Cystic lesions with enhancing mural nodules (Option B) Common Locations: Primarily found in the cerebellum and brainstem

questions.question: An infant undergoes a brain MRI that reveals a crescent-shaped mass filling the entire ventricular system, with the interhemispheric fissure not visible. The cerebrum exhibits a pancake-like appearance of the cerebral tissue, and there are no identifiable structures of the corpus callosum or falx cerebri. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis for this infant?
questions.explanation: a pancake-like tissue on the cerebrum and a crescent-shaped holo ventricle . Holoprosencephaly Holoprosencephaly is a forebrain malformation caused by incomplete separation of the cerebral hemispheres, associated with facial deformities. It has varying severity, classified into Alobar Semilobar Lobar Interhemispheric types Imaging Findings: Alobar : Crescent-shaped holo ventricle with no interhemispheric fissure Cerebrum has a pancake - like mass of tissue on imaging No interhemispheric fissure, corpus callosum, or falx cerebri Semilobar: Partial separation of the hemispheres, presenting with a single ventricle Mild facial abnormalities Lobar (Option D) : Near-normal separation of hemispheres with some continuous cortex between the frontal lobes Typically shows normal brain volume Interhemispheric (Syntelencephaly): Anterior and posterior fissures are present, but the middle lacks an interhemispheric fissure with fused frontal and parietal lobes Schizencephaly (Option B): Schizencephaly is a defect in the cerebral mantle characterized by a cleft that connects the calvarium with the lateral ventricles, lined with grey matter and leptomeninges. The cleft can be classified as: Open lip (wide-open defect) Closed lip (closed but lined with grey matter) Imaging Findings: CT: lateral ventricles may show clefts and abnormalities in the cortical mantle. MRI: Closed lip forms are best visualized showing abnormal cortical thickness due to polymicrogyria Potential contralateral developmental abnormalities are visualized as well Lissencephaly (Option C): Lissencephaly, or "smooth brain," involves abnormal neuronal migration resulting in a thickened cortex with few or no gyri, often associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum. It can be categorized into complete lissencephaly (no gyri) and incomplete lissencephaly (fewer, broader gyri). Imaging Findings: MRI: Shows a smooth cortical surface Shallow and wide Sylvian fissures A thin outer cortical layer with a thicker band of grey matter underneath

questions.question: The brain imaging of a child reveals the following: What is the classical appearance of the lateral ventricles in this image called?
questions.explanation: (colpocephaly) resembling a race car and hence called the race car appearance which is found in corpus callosum agenesis. Corpus callosum agenesis: The corpus callosum is part of major interhemispheric commissural connections and consists of the rostrum, genu, body, and splenium. Isthmus is the narrowing point between the body and splenium of the corpus callosum. The partial formation of the corpus callosum is called dysgenesis and the complete absence is agenesis. Axial Imaging: Lateral ventricles appear parallel with typical posterior enlargement known as colpocephaly resembling a “ race car ”. The third ventricle is positioned higher than normal. Normal convergence of the lateral ventricle bodies towards the midline is absent. Sagittal Imaging: Absence of the corpus callosum. Vertically oriented sulci extend down to the ventricle without the development of cingulate gyri. The cingulate sulcus is absent. Sunray appearance of gyri radiating outward in a radial pattern from the ventricle is seen. (Option B) Coronal Imaging: The absence of the corpus callosum is noted in the midline. The third ventricle appears elevated. Characteristic indentation on the medial aspect of the lateral ventricles due to the bundles of Probst represent white matter tracts unable to cross the midline. questions.question: A 3-month-old infant is evaluated for developmental delays and abnormal head shape. An MRI reveals a dysplastic cerebellum with an everted inferior vermis. Which type of Chiari malformation is most likely indicated by these findings?
questions.explanation: malformation. Chirari or Arnold-Chiari malformations: Chiari malformations involve the dislocation of the hindbrain into the spinal canal. Chiari described 4 types: Chiari I : often acquired and associated with conditions affecting intracranial or intraspinal pressure. Chiari II : primarily seen in pediatric cases and characterized by dysplastic cerebellum. Types III and IV : rarely seen. Chiari Type I lesion or cerebellar ectopia (Option A) Chiari Type II malformations Chiari Type III (Option C) Description Involves the descent of normal cerebellar hemispheres below the foramen magnum, often with pointed tonsils. Defined by a dysplastic cerebellum with an everted inferior vermis. This is a rare type. Involves herniation of the hindbrain (cerebellum with or without brainstem). Anatomical changes The cisterna magna is often obliterated. Medulla oblongata elongation occurs

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presents with progressive headaches, vision changes, and growth delay. Neurological examination reveals bitemporal hemianopia. MRI of the brain shows a large, lobulated, multiloculated cystic lesion with a small enhancing solid component and calcifications in the suprasellar region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: multiloculated cystic lesion in the suprasellar region , is characteristic of a craniopharyngioma , particularly the adamantinomatous subtype, which is more common in children. Craniopharyngioma (Option B) Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar tumors that develop from remnants of the craniopharyngeal duct or Rathke’s pouch . It compress Optic chaism leads to bitemporal hemianopia. Adamantinomatous subtype It is more common Seen in children Typically appear as large, lobulated, multiloculated cystic lesions with a small enhancing solid component and calcifications . Papillary subtype Seen in Adults Primarily solid lesion Rarely exhibit calcifications Pituitary Adenoma (Option A) Pituitary Microadenomas Less than 10 mm in size. Microadenomas appear isointense to the pituitary on T1-weighted images and slightly hyperintense on T2-weighted images. In dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI , they enhance slowly compared to the surrounding pituitary gland. Pituitary

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy presents with headache, nausea, and balance difficulties. MRI reveals a hyperdense mass in the midline cerebellar vermis, with surrounding vasogenic edema and hydrocephalus. The mass shows restricted diffusion on MRI and homogeneous contrast enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: vasogenic edema and associated symptoms like presents with headache, nausea, and balance difficulties are common in children with cerebellar tumors due to increased intracranial pressure and disruption of cerebellar function suggestive of Medulloblastoma . Ependymoma (Option A) Ependymomas are glial tumors originating from the ependymal cells lining the brain's ventricles Infratentorial (posterior fossa) tumors cause increased intracranial pressure and hydrocephalus. Supratentorial tumors cause focal neurological deficits, headaches, and seizures. Associated with neurofibromatosis 2 Posterior fossa ependymomas : Appear as intraventricular masses filling the 4th ventricle , often extending through the foramina of Luschka and Magendie, resembling a "plaster cast." Supratentorial ependymomas : Half are intraparenchymal. Ependymomas show heterogeneity with areas of necrosis, calcification, cystic changes, and hemorrhage. On MRI, they are hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2, with heterogeneous enhancement and possible restricted diffusion. Medulloblastoma (Option B)

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive SNHL and non-pulsatile tinnitus in the right ear. MRI reveals a solid, enhancing mass in the internal auditory canal extending into the cerebellopontine angle, creating an "ice cream cone" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: cerebellopontine angle , creating the characteristic "ice cream cone" appearance with clinical feature SNHL & tinnitus suggestive of Vestibular Schwannoma . Vestibular Schwannoma (Option C) Schwannomas are benign tumors that originate from Schwann cells forming the nerve sheath. Commonly arise from superior & inferior vestibular divisions of the 8th cranial nerve Usually solitary, B/L acoustic tumors are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) . presents with sensorineural hearing loss & nonpulsatile tinnitus . On contrast-enhanced scans, it appears as solid, nodular enhancing masses in the internal auditory canal extending into the cerebellopontine angle cistern . Extracanalicular extension can produce an "ice cream cone" appearance. Meningioma (Option D) Meningiomas arise from arachnoidal cap cells in the brain and spinal cord coverings. They are the most common benign intracranial tumors . Most common in females Mostly sporadic but can be linked to NF-2 or prior cranial irradiation. questions.question: A 27-year-old woman with a family history of an autosomal dominant genetic disorder presents with recurrent seizures and developmental delay. On physical examination, she has red papules on her face consistent with adenoma sebaceum. Which of the following is not a radiologic finding typically associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: characterized by seizures, developmental delay, and adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas). Sphenoid wing dysplasia is a radiological finding commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), not tuberous sclerosis (TS). Tuberous Sclerosis (TS): Multisystem hamartomatous genetic neurocutaneous syndrome. Autosomal dominant inheritance with TSC1 and TSC2 genes mutations. Classical triad: Intellectual impairment Epilepsy Adenoma sebaceum Radiological Features: Intracranial Manifestations: a. Cortical tubers: (Option A) Benign hamartomas found in the cerebral cortex. Detected in approximately 95% of patients with TS. MRI Appearance: T1-weighted sequences: Well-circumscribed areas of low signal intensity T2-weighted sequences: High signal intensity b. Subependymal nodules: (Option B) Common brain lesions found in patients with TS and represent as hamartomatous growths. CT: Useful for detecting subependymal nodules, which are commonly associated with calcification (88% of cases). MRI Appearance: T1-weighted images: Show intermediate signal intensity. T2-weighted images: Exhibit isointense to hyperintense signals. c. Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs): SEGAs are derived from subependymal nodules. MRI Appearance: T1-weighted images: Hypo- to isointense compared with the cortex. T2-weighted images: Heterogeneously iso- to hyperintense. d. White Matter (WM) Abnormalities: Hyperintense areas on T2-weighted images Hypointense areas on T1-weighted images 2. Pulmonary Manifestations: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (Option D) Multifocal micronodular pneumocyte hyperplasia (MMPH) 3. Cardiac Manifestation: Cardiac rhabdomyoma 4 . Renal Manifestation: Renal Angiomyolipoma

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient with a family history of an autosomal dominant condition was diagnosed with a mutation in chromosome 22 and advised to have an MRI every 2 years to monitor for tumors. An MRI scan was performed and shown below. Identify the radiological finding shown below that is most consistent with this chromosomal abnormality?
questions.explanation: characterized by vestibular schwannomas. On MRI, these tumors can exhibit an "ice cream cone" appearance in the cerebellopontine angle. Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF-2): (Option C) Autosomal dominant condition due to mutation on chromosome 22. Also referred to as MISME syndrome for M ultiple I nherited S chwannomas, M eningiomas and E pendymomas. NF2 often manifests clinically in early adulthood with symptoms related to vestibular schwannomas. Arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) and represent as cerebellopontine angle (CPA) mass. Extracanalicular extension may result in an "ice cream cone" appearance. Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1): Most common inherited central nervous system (CNS) disorder and autosomal dominant condition due to mutation on chromosome 17. Radiological Findings: 1. Plexiform neurofibromas: (Option D) Complex masses from peripheral nerve sheaths. Appear as thickened, firm masses or nodules that may deeply infiltrate

questions.question: A 2-week-old neonate is evaluated for failure to thrive and persistent tachycardia. A cranial MRI shows a large vascular malformation with multiple feeding arteries and a dilated vein of Galen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Mural type Vein of Galen Malformation
options.B: Choroidal type Vein of Galen Malformation

questions.explanation: failure due to high-output conditions. The MRI findings align with the choroidal type, which involves multiple feeding arteries . Vein of Galen Malformation It is an arteriovenous malformation (AVM) developing prenatally due to abnormal connections (arteriovenous fistulas) involving the median prosencephalic vein which is a precursor to the vein of Galen. Types of VGM: Choroidal type (Option B) Fed by multiple choroidal arteries forming a nidus anterior to the venous varix. Presents in the neonatal period with high-output heart failure . Mural type (Option A) Characterized by fewer, more defined fistulous connections within the wall of the venous varix. Presents later in infancy with symptoms such as hydrocephalus . The dilated median prosencephalic vein (MPV) appears as a fluid-filled, echo-free structure in the posterior midline, showing significant blood flow on Doppler examination. On T2-weighted images, dilated feeding and draining vessels appear as flow-voids . The primary treatment involves endovascular procedures. Arteriovenous (AV) malformation (Option C) AVM is an abnormal tangle of vessels connecting an artery to a vein without a normal capillary bed. Clinically present as Acute hemorrhage . AVMs consist of several components: Feeding arteries – supply blood to the malformation Nidus (meaning "nest") – the central part where abnormal connections occur Shunting arterioles – the main issue, causing direct blood flow from arteries to veins Interconnected venous loops Draining veins – carry blood away from the malformation Early appearance of draining veins during the arterial phase of cerebral angiography indicates the presence of an arteriovenous shunt. CECT shows a "bag of worms" appearance. Fast blood flow creates flow voids visible on T2-weighted images. Developmental venous anomaly (Option D) Congenital malformation of veins that drain the normal brain. It is the most common cerebrovascular malformation. "Caput medusae" sign (collection of dilated medullary veins converging into an enlarged transcortical or subependymal collector vein) is pathognomonic and is observed in the venous phase of angiography.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a 2-week history of worsening headache, fever, and progressive neurological deficits, including weakness in his right arm. He has no significant past medical history. On examination, he exhibits right-sided hemiparesis and mild confusion. Blood tests show mild leukocytosis. A CT image is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: brain abscess , especially when surrounded by edema . The presence of fever, acute neurological symptoms and mild Leukocytosis further supports this diagnosis. Brain abscess Most brain abscesses in immunocompetent patients are bacterial, predominantly from streptococci. Causes : Hematogenous dissemination Penetrating trauma Direct spread from nearby infections (e.g., frontal sinusitis or mastoiditis) Bloodborne infections often target the territory of the middle cerebral arteries, especially the frontoparietal region. Abscesses are frequently subcortical or periventricular. Metastases (Option A) may also appear as ring-enhancing lesions but usually occur in patients

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with epilepsy and progressive memory loss over the past year. Neuroimaging reveals hippocampal volume loss and abnormal signal intensity on high-resolution coronal MRI. The internal laminated architecture of the hippocampus is disrupted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: internal laminated architecture of the hippocampus , all of which are hallmark findings of Mesial Temporal Sclerosis .It is often associated with epilepsy, particularly temporal lobe epilepsy, and can lead to progressive memory loss, which aligns with the patient's symptoms. Mesial temporal sclerosis (MTS) MTS primarily affects the hippocampus , a key region in the medial temporal lobe responsible for memory . Best visualized on high-resolution coronal MRI which demonstrates Hippocampa Volume loss. Abnormal signal. Loss of normal internal laminated architecture. MTS may cause atrophy in the ipsilateral mammillary body or fornix due to their connection within the medial limbic (Papez) circuit. Devic’s disease Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) typically presents with optic neuritis and transverse myelitis, along with additional demyelination. It has overlapping clinical and radiographic features of multiple sclerosis. Antibodies involved in NMO target astrocyte aquaporin-4 channels, myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein, and neurofascin at the node of Ranvier. Spinal cord involvement typically presents as a high T2 signal that spans at least 3 vertebral segments, referred to as a longitudinally

questions.question: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and memory impairment. He has a history of Alcoholic Liver Disease. An MRI is ordered to assess any potential brain damage due to chronic alcohol abuse. The MRI reveals signaling abnormalities. Which of the following locations are likely to show abnormal signals? Locations: Mammillary bodies Periventricular grey matter Thalamus Corpus callosum Hippocampus
questions.explanation: mammillary bodies, periventricular grey matter, and the thalamus. These areas are particularly vulnerable to thiamine deficiency, often seen in alcoholics. Other areas like the corpus callosum and hippocampus can be affected in other conditions but are not primary locations for damage. Chronic Alcoholism Chronic alcoholism can lead to several severe neurological conditions, many of which are due to vitamin deficiencies or electrolyte imbalances that result from prolonged alcohol abuse. Three major conditions associated with chronic alcoholism are Wernicke’s encephalopathy, Marchiafava-Bignami Disease (MBD), and Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM) / Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (ODS). Wernicke's Encephalopathy Pathophysiology Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency caused by chronic alcoholism, leading to impaired glucose metabolism and brain dysfunction, particularly in memory and coordination areas. Clinical Features Mnemonic: GOA G lobal Confusion: Mental disorientation, concentration issues, memory loss. O phthalmoplegia: Paralysis or weakness of eye muscles, nystagmus, or double vision. A taxia: Gait and stance disturbances due to cerebellar dysfunction. Progression Can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome, characterized by irreversible memory deficits and confabulation. Diagnostic Test Red Blood Cell Transketolase Test: Assesses thiamine deficiency. MRI Findings Signaling abnormalities seen in Mammillary Bodies: Atrophy or hyperintensity. Periventricular Gray Matter Thalamus. Midbrain Colliculi. Fornix involvement. Treatment Immediate Thiamine Supplementation: Administer thiamine (typically 100 mg IV or IM). Glucose Infusion: After thiamine is given, a glucose-containing solution can be infused, Marchiafava-Bignami Disease (MBD) Pathophysiology Rare condition affecting chronic alcoholics, causing demyelination and necrosis of the corpus callosum. The mechanism is not fully understood, but it's linked to malnutrition and chronic alcohol toxicity. Clinical Features Cognitive Disturbances: Progressive dementia, confusion, memory loss. Motor Symptoms: Seizures, gait abnormalities, spasticity. Altered Sensorium: Lethargy, stupor, or coma. Progression Can lead to severe cognitive impairment, spasticity, coma, or death. The condition may worsen rapidly or fluctuate over time. MRI Findings Hyperintense lesions on T2-weighted and FLAIR sequences in the corpus callosum, especially the body and splenium. Signs: 1. "Butterfly-shaped" lesions in the corpus callosum 2. Sandwich sign Treatment Thiamine and vitamin B-complex supplementation is usually administered. Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (ODS) / Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM): Pathophysiology Occurs due to rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia, leading to osmotic shifts and destruction of the myelin

questions.question: Assertion: The absence of the swallow tail on MRI is indicative of Parkinson's disease. Reason: It represents the characteristic loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, leading to specific changes in the brain's morphology.

options.A: Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion.
options.B: Both the assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion.
options.C: The assertion is true, but the reason is false.
options.D: The assertion is false, but the reason is true.

questions.explanation: assertion. particularly the loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra. This loss leads to specific morphological changes in the putamen and other structures, supporting the assertion that its absence is indicative of Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's Disease (PD) Parkinson's Disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder marked by motor symptoms like bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors, primarily due to dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra pars compacta of the midbrain. Diagnosis typically involves clinical evaluation, though neuroimaging can offer insights into disease pathophysiology and assist in distinguishing PD from "Parkinson plus" syndromes. Normal and Abnormal Radiological Findings Normal Midbrain: Split/Swallow Tail Sign (Figure 1A): In healthy individuals, MRI imaging of the midbrain reveals a characteristic "swallow tail" sign due to the presence of nigrosomes (distinctive structures within the substantia nigra). This sign is indicative of normal dopaminergic function. Parkinson's Disease (Figure 1B): Absence of Swallow Tail Sign: In patients with PD, the swallow tail sign is absent. This finding suggests a loss of nigrosomes due to the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons. Loss of Nigrosomes: MRI findings will demonstrate the absence of nigrosomes in the substantia nigra, correlating with the loss of dopamine production. Parkinson Plus Syndromes "Parkinson plus" syndromes are atypical parkinsonian disorders that share core features with Parkinson’s Disease, such as bradykinesia and rigidity, but with distinct additional symptoms: Dementia: Early cognitive decline. Autonomic Dysfunction: Symptoms like orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence, and sexual dysfunction. Common examples of Parkinson plus syndromes include: Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) (also known as Steele-Richardson-Olszewski Syndrome) Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) Corticobasal Degeneration (CBD) Radiological Considerations for Other Parkinson Plus Syndromes Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) / Steele-Richardson-Olszewski Syndrome It typically presents with early postural instability and difficulty with eye movements, especially vertical gaze palsy. PSP is associated with midbrain atrophy, which is easily identified on MRI. Mickey Mouse Sign: One key radiological sign seen in PSP is the "Mickey Mouse sign" on axial MRI imaging of the midbrain. This occurs due to atrophy of the midbrain, giving it the shape of Mickey Mouse's head. Hummingbird Sign: Seen on sagittal MRI views of the midbrain. This appearance is due to atrophy of the midbrain, which gives it the shape of a bird in flight, with the preserved pons forming the body and the atrophic midbrain forming the head. Multiple System Atrophy (MSA): MRI may show atrophy of the putamen and cerebellar structures. The presence of the "hot cross bun" sign in the pons is characteristic of MSA, especially when there is cerebellar involvement (MSA-C). Corticobasal Degeneration (CBD): MRI findings in CBD may show asymmetrical cortical atrophy and basal ganglia changes.

questions.question: Match the following diseases and their associated radiological signs Radiological Sign Disease 1) Giant Panda sign a) Ceruloplasmin Defeciency 2) tram track calcification b) Fahr’s Disease 3) Eye of the tiger sign c) Sturge Weber syndrome 4) Bracket Calcification d) Hallervorden-Spatz disease
questions.explanation: Wilson’s Disease Genetic disorder leading to low levels of ceruloplasmin, impairing copper transport and resulting in copper accumulation. MRI: "Face of the giant panda" sign in the midbrain; signal abnormalities in basal ganglia due to copper deposits. KF ring: Golden-brown ring in the cornea due to copper accumulation. Note: Sarcoidosis: Gallium scan: Distinctive "panda sign" showing tracer uptake in the lacrimal, parotid, and salivary glands. This should not be confused with the panda sign of Wilson's disease seen on MRI. Hallervorden-Spatz Disease (PKAN) Iron accumulation in the brain, especially the globus pallidus. MRI: "Eye of the tiger" sign on T2-weighted imaging. Central hyperintense gliotic area surrounded by hypointense iron deposits, resembling a tiger's eye. Fahr’s Disease (Basal Ganglia Calcification) Idiopathic or secondary to metabolic disorders (e.g., hypoparathyroidism). CT scan: Symmetrical calcifications in the basal ganglia, thalamus, dentate nucleus, and other brain structures. Bracket calcifications: Curvilinear hyperdensities forming a bracket-like appearance around the basal ganglia. Sturge-Weber Syndrome Congenital neurocutaneous disorder with vascular malformations. CT scan: "Tram-track" calcifications along the gyri of the cerebral cortex, especially in the occipital and parietal lobes. MRI: Cortical atrophy and leptomeningeal enhancement.

questions.question: An 80-year-old male presents to his physician with complaints of difficulty sleeping and frequently waking up during the night. questions.explanation: low CD4 (<100 cells/mm³), and the MRI shows the “target sign” confirming the diagnosis. Toxoplasmosis Toxoplasma gondii, a protozoan, causes toxoplasmosis. questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents with recurrent seizures. MRI imaging reveals as follows: Based on the MRI findings, which stage of neurocysticercosis is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation: signifies the vesicular stage of neurocysticercosis . Neurocysticercosis Neurocysticercosis is the most critical parasitic disease of the central nervous system (CNS) globally. It is caused by the encysted larvae of the tapeworm Taenia solium , transmitted through: Ingesting eggs from undercooked pork Fecal-oral transmission between humans Larvae are spread to neural, muscular, and ocular tissues via the bloodstream. The symptoms typically appear around 5 years after initial infection and are non-specific; 50%–70% of patients present with epilepsy. Larvae can infect the brain parenchyma, subarachnoid space, and ventricles. The most common form is parenchymal, followed by intraventricular. Mixed types may also occur. Imaging Stages of Parenchymal Neurocysticercosis Vesicular stage Viable larva with a scolex (worm head). Cysts have thin walls, minimal enhancement, and no surrounding edema. Cyst fluid resembles cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and allows unrestricted water diffusion. The scolex may appear hyperintense on T1 , FLAIR , and DWI images. Colloidal vesicular stage (Option C) Larva begins to break down, triggering an immune response. Characterized by ring-enhancing lesions , perilesional edema , and mass effect .
